text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers this morning.

Warsaw's heat and power generating plants want to invest in the mass media and leisure industries. Among other goals they are seeking shares in Nasza Telewizja (Our Television), a station which has won a licence for a trans-regional network.
Royal Dutch/Shell Group will formally open a liquid petroleum gas plant in the central city of Lodz. Shell Managing Director Steve Miller said Shell would invest $60 million in Poland next year.
The amended offer submitted by Polish-French consortium Hachette-Wydawcy Prasy for the Polish news-stand chain Ruch SA, is its final proposal, Gazeta Wyborcza learned unofficially.

The main failings of the 1997 budget draft are low spending on public safety, defence and the justice system as well as a growth of internal debt, says Adam Smith Centre analyst Krzysztof Dzierzawski.
Deutsche Bank Polska S.A. Chairman Georg Krapp said Warsaw has a good chance of becoming a major financial centre of Central Europe.
Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz yesterday appointed a Civil Service Council to oversee administrative appointments. It has 24 members, politicians, officials and academics.
The European Union aims to devote 950,000 ECU for a STEP programme in Poland devoted to financing selected services for small and medium-sized companies.
The Progress National Investment Fund aims to prepare an issue prospectus.
A package of legislation for reform of the social security system will reach the lower house of parliament in March next year, Labour Minister Andrzej Baczkowski said.

According to unofficial information, clothes maker Zaklady Odziezowe Bytom, which has been offering investors 250,000 series B shares at 27 zlotys each since the beginning of October, will probably take advantage help from guarantees.
KPBP BICK plans to buy shares or stakes in other construction companies. It is especially interested in road builders.

Sobieslaw Zasada Ltd and Dailer-Benz InterServices Aktiengesellschaft opened a leasing firm, Mercedes Benz Leasing Polska with initial capital of 10 million zlotys. Sobieslaw Zasada has 25 percent of the shares, and the German firm holds the rest.
